page.title: 16SADDLEWORTH CUSTOMS
page.content: The annual rushcart festival is a popular event. In the 19th century local villages each built their own rushcarts & paraded them round, but today there is only one which is dragged around all the local villages by teams of Morris Dancers.It ends up at Saddleworth Church, where rushes are taken in to the church during the service, & afterwards there is much celebrating, drinking & dancing. There is also a well-dressing outside the church. Whit Friday Walks are a more solemn affair. Wakes holidays are still taken, with local businesses, schools, etc. closing down for 2 weeks, & also for the traditional 'September Week'. Morris dancing & clog dancing are popular, with clogs being made loacally. Brass bands are still thriving here. Fell races take place over the hills for the active!
